2. ğŸ”¹ Few-Shot Prompting

Definition:
Provide the model with a few examples to guide its output.

Prompt Example:

Response Example:

  • Helps the model mimic the style and structure of given examples.
  • One-Shot Prompting = providing only one example.
  • Effective when you need consistent formatting or tone in the output.

3. ğŸ”¹ Chain-of-Thought (CoT) Prompting

Definition:
Guide the model by dividing the task into step-by-step reasoning.

Prompt Example:

Response Example:

  1. Rover, a curious dog, lives in a quiet neighborhood.
  2. One day, a necklace goes missingâ€¦
  3. Rover follows footprints to the parkâ€¦
  4. He finds the necklace hidden by a magpieâ€¦
  • Produces more structured and logical responses.
  • Useful for problem-solving tasks like math, reasoning, or multi-step workflows.
  • Can be combined with Zero-Shot or Few-Shot prompting.

4. ğŸ”¹ Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)

Definition:
Combine the modelâ€™s generative ability with external data sources to create more accurate, context-aware responses.

How it works:

  1. Query is sent to the model.
  2. Relevant information is retrieved from an external source (e.g., Amazon S3, vector DB).
  3. The retrieved data is augmented into the prompt.
  4. The model generates a context-rich answer.

  • Ensures outputs are grounded in real or domain-specific knowledge.
  • In AWS Bedrock, RAG is often implemented with a Knowledge Base and vector search (KNN).

  • Use Few-Shot for consistent style and formatting.

  • Use RAG when accuracy and domain-specific knowledge are critical.

ğŸ¤– LLM Text Generation & Prompt Optimization

1. How Text is Generated in an LLM

When a model generates text, it predicts the next word based on probabilities.

Example:
â€œAfter the rain, the streets wereâ€¦â€
Possible next words and probabilities:

  • wet (0.40)
  • flooded (0.25)
  • slippery (0.15)
  • empty (0.10)
  • muddy (0.05)
  • clean (0.03)
  • blocked (0.02)

The model randomly selects a word according to these probabilities.

2. Prompt Performance Optimization

ğŸ”¹ System Prompts

  • Define how the model should behave and reply.
  • Example: â€œYou are a teacher in AWS Cloud.â€

ğŸ”¹ Temperature (0 to 1)

  • Controls creativity.
  • Low (e.g., 0.2): Conservative, repetitive, focused on likely answers.
  • High (e.g., 1.0): More diverse, creative, unpredictable, less coherent.

ğŸ”¹ Top P (Nucleus Sampling)

  • Value: 0â€“1.
  • Low (e.g., 0.25): Only top 25% likely words â†’ coherent output.
  • High (e.g., 0.99): Considers more words â†’ diverse, creative output.

ğŸ”¹ Top K

  • Limits number of candidate words.
  • Low (e.g., 10): Considers top 10 words â†’ focused, coherent output.
  • High (e.g., 500): Considers many â†’ more variety, creativity.

ğŸ”¹ Length

  • Maximum output length.

ğŸ”¹ Stop Sequences

  • Tokens that signal the model to stop generating.

âœ… Exam Tip (AWS AI Practitioner):
Know the definitions of System Prompts, Temperature, Top P, Top K, Length, Stop Sequences and what happens with low vs. high values.

3. Prompt Latency

Latency = how fast the model responds.
Impacted by:

  • Model size (larger = slower).
  • Model type (e.g., LLaMA vs Claude).
  • Input tokens (longer prompt = slower).
  • Output tokens (longer generation = slower).

âš ï¸ Not impacted by: Temperature, Top P, or Top K.

âœ… Exam Tip: Expect a question about what affects latency and what does not.

4. Practical Example

Prompt: â€œWrite a short story about a robot learning to cook.â€

  • Low Creativity (Temp=0.2, Top P=0.25, Top K=10) â†’ Safe, repetitive story.
  • High Creativity (Temp=1.0, Top P=0.99, Top K=500) â†’ Imaginative, unique story (e.g., robot making crepes with optical sensors).

5. Key Takeaways

  • Temperature = randomness/creativity.
  • Top P = probability threshold (percentile of words).
  • Top K = number of candidate words.
  • System Prompt = role/behavior definition.
  • Length/Stop Sequences = control output size and ending.
  • Latency = depends on model size, type, and token count (not sampling parameters).

ğŸ“˜ Good to Remember for AWS Exam:

  • Be clear about how each parameter influences output.
  • Understand latency factors.
  • Expect scenario questions like: â€œWhich parameter ensures more coherent answers?â€ or â€œWhat does not affect latency?â€.

entry.content:
ğŸ“˜ Prompt Engineering

What is Prompt Engineering?

Prompt Engineering is the process of designing, refining, and
optimizing prompts to guide a foundation model (FM) or large language
model (LLM) toward producing the best possible output for your needs.

A naÃ¯ve prompt gives little guidance and leaves interpretation up to
the model.
Example: â€œSummarize what is AWS.â€
This works, but the answer may not be clear or focused.

By contrast, Prompt Engineering uses a structured approach to
improve results.

Components of an Effective Prompt

  1. Instructions â€“ What the model should do (e.g., summarize,
    explain, compare).\
  2. Context â€“ Additional background that helps guide the response.\
  3. Input Data â€“ The text, question, or data you want the model to
    work with.\
  4. Output Indicator â€“ The desired format or style of the answer
    (e.g., 2â€“3 sentences, bullet points, JSON).

Example: Enhanced Prompt

NaÃ¯ve Prompt: â€œSummarize what is AWS.â€

Enhanced Prompt:
â€œWrite a concise summary that captures the main points of an article
about learning AWS (Amazon Web Services).
Ensure that the summary is clear and informative, focusing on key
services relevant to beginners.
Include details about learning resources and career benefits.
I am teaching a beginnerâ€™s AWS course.
Provide a 2â€“3 sentence summary that captures the essence of the
article.â€

This approach makes the task more precise and tailored to the userâ€™s
goal.

Negative Prompting

Negative prompting explicitly tells the model what not to include.
This helps: - Avoid Unwanted Content â€“ Prevents irrelevant or
unnecessary details.\

  • Maintain Focus â€“ Keeps the response on-topic.\
  • Enhance Clarity â€“ Avoids complex jargon or deep technical detail
    if not needed.

Example with Negative Prompting:
â€œSummarize an article about AWS for beginners.
Focus on key services, learning resources, and career benefits.
Do not include technical configurations, in-depth tutorials, or
personal anecdotes.
Provide a clear, beginner-friendly 2â€“3 sentence summary.â€

Why It Matters (AWS Exam Relevance)

For AWS AI Practitioner and related certifications, you should know: -
Prompt Engineering improves AI model accuracy and usefulness.\

  • AWS exams may ask about the difference between naÃ¯ve prompts,
    enhanced prompts, and negative prompts    .\
  • Understanding how to guide model behavior is key in real-world AI
    applications, from summarization to chatbots.

Key Takeaways

  • NaÃ¯ve prompts = vague and open-ended.\
  • Enhanced prompts = structured with instructions, context, input, and
    output format.\
  • Negative prompts = control what not to generate.\
  • Together, these techniques ensure clearer, more accurate, and
    useful outputs    .

ğŸ“˜ Amazon Bedrock â€“ Pricing & Model Improvement

1ï¸âƒ£ Pricing Options

ğŸ”¹ On-Demand (Pay-as-you-go)

  • How it works: Pay only for what you use, like an electricity bill.
  • Pricing basis
    • Text Models â†’ Input/Output token count
    • Embedding Models â†’ Input token count
    • Image Models â†’ Number of images generated
  • Available Models: Base Models only
  • âœ… Pros: Flexible, good for unpredictable workloads
  • âŒ Cons: Can become expensive if used continuously over time

ğŸ”¹ Batch Mode (Bulk processing, up to 50% discount)

  • How it works: Group multiple requests together â†’ results stored as a single file in Amazon S3
  • Discount: Up to 50% cheaper
  • âœ… Pros: Great for large-scale processing, strong cost savings
  • âŒ Cons: No real-time response, results are delayed
  • Best use case: Large batch jobs where immediate results are not required

ğŸ”¹ Provisioned Throughput (Reserved capacity, guaranteed performance)

  • How it works: Like a gym membership â€” reserve processing capacity for a set period (e.g., 1â€“6 months)
  • Guaranteed performance: Ensures a maximum number of input/output tokens per minute
  • Available Models: Base, Fine-tuned, and Custom Models
  • âœ… Pros: Stable performance and capacity, supports custom models
  • âŒ Cons: Not a cost-saving option, purpose is performance guarantee

2ï¸âƒ£ Model Improvement Techniques (Low â†’ High Cost)

1. Prompt Engineering

  • Improve results simply by optimizing prompts
  • No extra computation â†’ Lowest cost

2. Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG)

  • Uses an external knowledge database (Vector DB)
  • No model retraining â†’ relatively low cost
  • Additional cost for building and maintaining the database

RAG = â€œModel + Search functionâ€ â†’ lets the model find external knowledge it doesnâ€™t already know.

3. Instruction-based Fine-tuning

  • Fine-tune the model with labeled data and specific instructions
  • Requires extra computation â†’ Higher cost

4. Domain Adaptation Fine-tuning

  • Retrain the model with a large domain-specific dataset
  • Requires extensive data preparation + heavy computation â†’ Highest cost

  • Token management â†’ main driver of cost savings

  • Adjust hyperparameters (Temperature, Top-K, Top-P)
    • Affects model behavior but not pricing
